title: 107_s1625
content: The "Children's Health Equity Act of 2001" allows for up to 4 state waivers to use Title XXI allotments to increase Medicaid children's enrollment. In this section, key definitions include terms like "child," "child health assistance," "enhanced FMAP," "Federal medical assistance percentage," "poverty line," "Secretary," and "State child health plan." These definitions are crucial for understanding the provisions outlined in the text. The Secretary will approve up to 4 waiver applications for states meeting specific requirements related to SCHIP income eligibility and benefits for children. The State child health plan must have the highest income eligibility standard allowed under title XXI of the Social Security Act, accept applications for all children, and provide benefits statewide. The State child health plan must provide benefits to all eligible children without imposing waiting lists or numerical limitations for those with family income at or below 200 percent of the poverty line. Additionally, the State must implement at least 4 specific policies and procedures related to coverage of children under titles XIX and XXI of the Social Security Act. The State child health plan must provide benefits to eligible children without asset tests, with 12-month continuous enrollment, and without regular redetermination. Automatic reassessment of eligibility is also required for children under the plan. The State must use the same verification policies for initial eligibility determinations and redeterminations under titles XIX and XXI, including automatic reassessment of eligibility. Outstationing enrollment staff at designated facilities for processing applications is also required. The Secretary authorizes payment to States with approved waivers under section 2104 of the Social Security Act for medical assistance expenditures under title XIX. The Secretary determines total medical assistance expenditures for children under title XIX of the Social Security Act in the State for fiscal year 1995, including any increased expenditures and bonus amounts. The total amount determined under subparagraph (C) and the difference between the enhanced FMAP and the Federal medical assistance percentage for the State for the fiscal year. Children eligible for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act, including those with family income exceeding the highest eligibility level and those who would be considered disabled under section 1614(a)(3)(C) of the Social Security Act.
